course_name: GEOG407 - Environmental Hydrology of Terrestrial Ecosystems (0.50)
major_name: Earth Systems Science Specialization
topics: Environmental Hydrology of Terrestrial Ecosystems Winter 2025
merrin.macrae@uwaterloo.ca
Email: mmacrae@uwaterloo.ca
This course focuses on ecological and biogeochemical processes that are linked to the terrestrial hydrological cycle and how these relate to the management of natural resources.

The objectives of this interdisciplinary course are to explore topics that integrate ecosystem processes with physical hydrology and examine the impacts of human activities on ecohydrological and hydrochemical processes within terrestrial systems.
Understand linkages between hydrological and biogeochemical processes in the natural environment
Understand the implications of land use change and climate change on selected ecosystems
Analyze and visualize numerical data and write laboratory reports
Jan. 14 Watershed Hydrology Field and Lab Methods for Water Quality 1 *Safety/services & orientation of labs; TAs do overview of labs
Feb. 25 Wetlands and In-stream Processes  *Data Lab Part 2
Mar. 4 Impacts of Climate Change on hydrology and biogeochem: case study of subarctic and temperate peatlands *Data Lab Part 2
Each lab section will attend a total of two “practical labs” – one will be held outdoors in the field and the other will be held indoors in a laboratory setting.
For the indoor lab, students will learn standard techniques for the processing of samples and the analyses of key water quality parameters.
This time of year can be cold and wet – students must have proper clothing to stay warm and dry for 1.5 hours in the field.
The meticulous construction of lab reports or field reports is a hallmark of any undergraduate education in geography and environmental sciences.
The careful analysis of hydrological and water quality data is also critical in water quality research and is a skill necessary to succeed in jobs in this field.

These labs will introduce you to the exploration and analysis of standard parameters in water quality analysis, by working with the data and constructing informative tables and graphs and describing what your data is showing you.
The exam will consist of a series of multiple choice, short answer and longer essay-style questions.

This course includes the independent development and practice of specific skills, such as understanding the importance of proper data collection and analysis, as well as the interpretation of these data.

major_name: Earth Systems Science Specialization
topics: Field Ecology Winter 2025
**We aim to respond to forum posts and necessary emails within general workday hours (8:30 AM – 4:30 PM) and within 24hrs, except over weekends and holidays.

Introduces the main concepts and principles of ecology; the cycling of elements; energetics and structural organization of major ecological systems; population dynamics; impact of natural resource management practices and urban and industrial development on the environment; incorporating environmental quality considerations into development activities.
The lab sessions include field trips to study natural and disturbed ecosystems, urban and applied ecology.
View requirements for ENVS 200

Such knowledge, called ecoliteracy, will provide a critical basis for your engagement in the 21st century, the “century of the environment”—not least because so many of the environmental issues we face derive in part from a limited understanding of how we are embedded within and dependent upon ecological systems.

Field ecology necessarily harbours an ethical component both because of our natural affinity for life (or ‘biophilia’) and because questions of ecological ‘impact’ and 'quality’ are necessarily value-laden.

In summary, this course introduces the main concepts and principles of ecology; the cycling of elements; energetics and structural organization of major ecological systems; population dynamics; impact of natural resource management practices and urban and industrial development on the environment; incorporating environmental quality considerations into development activities.
The lab sessions include field trips to study natural and disturbed ecosystems, urban and applied ecology.
By the end of this course, you should be on a path to life-long learning as an ecologically-literate citizen.
Demonstrate how these principles apply to real-world situations (in context of lab activities, assignments, and labs), including human interactions with the natural world.
Articulate the elements of scientific inquiry as they apply to ecology/

These course learning outcomes will not only prepare you to be an informed citizen and member of the community of life on earth, but also provide the basis for knowledge, humility, and wisdom in your dealings with ecological problems in your daily life and eventual career.

major_name: Earth Systems Science Specialization
topics: Dr. Richard Petrone                                                                                       Winter 2025
Lab Co-ordinator:
TBA
An introduction to the fundamental processes governing climate and hydrological systems and the links between them.
It starts with a discussion of basic atmospheric and hydrological processes and traces the flow of energy and water between the earth's surface and the atmosphere.
This course provides students with a thorough background of the fundamental processes governing the climate and hydrological systems, and the links between them.
The course first reviews fundamental atmospheric and hydrologic processes, and traces the flow of energy and water between the Earth’s surface and the atmosphere.
Through the use of group activities students will be given the opportunity to gain experience manipulating real hydrological and meteorological data and instrumentation.

This course will serve as an introduction to near-surface hydroclimatic processes, their feedbacks and climate change, forming essential background for upper level courses in climate change, hydroclimatology and environmental sciences and studies in general.
The fundamental knowledge and skills developed in this course will provide students with the basis to appreciate and understand the natural hydrologic and climate systems.
It also provides the required foundation for advanced courses in climatology and hydrology.

The objective of this course is to provide students with the background to further their interests in weather and climate, and provide the theoretical foundations for upper level science and management courses.
To identify the key boundary layer processes that drive the hydroclimate system.
To identify and evaluate the characteristics of different land-use types and ecosystems that drive their hydroclimatic regimes.

course_name: GEOG306 - Human Dimensions of Natural Hazards (0.50)
major_name: Earth Systems Science Specialization
topics: Human Dimensions of Natural Hazards - GEOG 306 Winter 2025
E. Mohammadi
E-mail:            elham.mohammadi@uwaterloo.ca

The physical nature of a wide range of geophysical and biophysical hazards will be explored, paying particular attention to the ways in which hazards become dangerous to humans, and the pathways by which humans can either increase or decrease their vulnerability in the face of natural hazards.
Natural hazards and associated disasters are, in part, a product of inappropriate human modifications or management of the natural landscape.
Throughout the course, case studies and examples drawn from countries and regions around the world will be used to clarify conceptual and methodological issues.
Appreciate the physical processes associated with various natural hazards, with a focus on geophysical, meteorological, and hydrological hazards.
Appreciate the key components of preparing for disasters.
Apply knowledge to compare hazards theory with real-world case studies.
Theme 1: Introduction
Introduction to Course, Natural Hazards, and Disasters
Defining and Measuring Disasters
Theme 3: Prevention and Mitigation of Disasters
Theme 3: Prevention and Mitigation of Disasters
Theme 3: Prevention and Mitigation of Disasters
Disasters in the Media and Risk Perception
Disasters in the Media and Risk Perception Cont'd + Hazard focus: Wildfires
Key Considerations in BBB
Livelihoods & Psychological Recovery
Comparative Analysis of Responses to Specific Disasters 20%
Please note that these activities are designed to reinforce key concepts and promote collaboration.
Description: Engage with the concept of vulnerability by crafting a compelling narrative that could be used in a media piece (e.g., news).
Select and compare two disaster response efforts for similar events across different regions.

major_name: Earth Systems Science Specialization
topics: Notice of Recording
Spatial Analysis Winter 2025
Email:                     dtrobins@uwaterloo.ca
Email:                      lqzhao@uwaterloo.ca
Advanced quantitative analysis in a spatial context.
Today, spatial analysis is mainly based on statistical techniques and geoprocessing using geographic information systems (GIS).

The spatial character of data implies several methodological challenges in spatial data analysis especially related to the spatial dependence of the data, which often invalidates non-spatial modeling and evaluation approaches and leads to special techniques for spatial sampling and spatial regression modeling.
In addition, selected topics such as spatial data mining and spatial analysis software may be addressed, depending upon the progress of the course.
Several real-world applications of spatial analysis techniques will be discussed and provide context for course assignments.
develop a general understanding of a variety of spatial modelling techniques
interpret and critically discuss spatial models and their results
The lecture will be used to introduce the theory and concepts behind spatial analysis methods as well as to demonstrate techniques that will aid the completion of lab assignments.
1  Jan 8 Introduction to Spatial Analysis 1, 2
Feb 12 Describing and Analyzing Fields 9
7  Feb 26 Describing and Analyzing Fields  9, 10
10  Mar 19 Landscape Metrics and Applications of Spatial Analysis
Spatial Data Analysis: an Introduction for GIS Users.
Principles of Geographical Information Systems.

There are no serious programming requirements or extensive prior knowledge of geographic information systems to complete the assignments in this course.

course_name: GEOG368 - Ecology and Conservation for Planning (0.50)
major_name: Earth Systems Science Specialization
topics: Ecology and Conservation for Planning Winter 2025
This course provides students with a critical understanding of the relationship between human development and natural environments.
Students will develop an understanding of core ecological principles and how these can be taken up in plans and policies to promote nature conservation in urban and rural environments.

The course will include examples of how planners mitigate the environmental impacts of development of land, allotment of open space and parks, and conservation of sensitive areas and species in both urban and rural contexts.

major_name: Earth Systems Science Specialization
topics: This course reviews the physical and chemical processes, environmental assessment techniques and best management practices related to stormwater management in the urban systems.
Stormwater management is an evolving field of study that includes aspects of environmental design, engineering, chemistry, hydrology, planning, finance, and public administration.

This course reviews the principles of urban stormwater management to provide a practical understanding of the development and implementation of effective management plans to mitigate environmental impacts of stormwater in urban environments.
Current design principles and their implementation in modern planning practices for stormwater management in urban watersheds are reviewed.

major_name: Earth Systems Science Specialization
topics: Notice of Recording
Spatial Analysis Winter 2025
Email:                     dtrobins@uwaterloo.ca
Email:                      lqzhao@uwaterloo.ca
Advanced quantitative analysis in a spatial context.
Today, spatial analysis is mainly based on statistical techniques and geoprocessing using geographic information systems (GIS).

The spatial character of data implies several methodological challenges in spatial data analysis especially related to the spatial dependence of the data, which often invalidates non-spatial modeling and evaluation approaches and leads to special techniques for spatial sampling and spatial regression modeling.
In addition, selected topics such as spatial data mining and spatial analysis software may be addressed, depending upon the progress of the course.
Several real-world applications of spatial analysis techniques will be discussed and provide context for course assignments.
develop a general understanding of a variety of spatial modelling techniques
interpret and critically discuss spatial models and their results
The lecture will be used to introduce the theory and concepts behind spatial analysis methods as well as to demonstrate techniques that will aid the completion of lab assignments.

major_name: Earth Systems Science Specialization
topics: RCH 211
Emphasis on concepts related to fluvial processes, river mechanics, the relationship between environmental change and river regime.
Fluvial geomorphology is the scientific study of river landforms and the processes that create them.

A working knowledge of fluvial processes has important practical environmental science, watershed management and engineering applications and is relevant to many other fields of environmental enquiry such as environmental engineering, watershed planning, source water protection, forestry, and risk management.
This course will examine a range of physical and chemical processes that create micro and macro-scale landforms over a range of spatial and temporal scales.
Implications of these processes for environmental management in the context of environmental change will be considered.

major_name: Earth Systems Science Specialization
topics: This course provides a comprehensive overview of the cryosphere and cryosphere-atmosphere interactions.

Topics covered include the material and thermodynamic properties of snow and ice, the role of the cryosphere in weather and climate, and the response of the cryosphere to climate change (past, present, and future).
Describe the fundamental material properties of snow and ice, including crystal structures, phase transitions, and thermodynamic behavior, and relate these properties to cryospheric processes.
Explain the role of the various elements of the cryosphere in weather and climate.
Explain the response of the various elements of the cryosphere to changing weather and climate.

Explain the impacts of climate change on the cryosphere, both in terms of observed trends and projected future changes, considering the implications for sea level rise, freshwater resources, and polar ecosystems.
Identify historical and state-of-the-art datasets, including field observations and remote sensing data, needed to document the current state of the cryosphere.
Identify field instruments for measuring cryospheric parameters, such as snow depth, ice thickness, and permafrost temperature.
Conduct basic simulations with cryosphere process models, such as snow and lake ice models.
Synthesize complex cryospheric data and model outputs to assess the broader implications for climate science, global carbon cycling, and human societies.
Communicate research findings and insights related to the cryosphere effectively through written reports and oral presentations.
Introduction to the Cryosphere
Material Properties of Snow and Ice
Analysis and interpretation of field-based measurements
Snow and Ice Thermodynamics
Analysis and interpretation of field-based measurements
Glaciers and Ice Sheets
Deadlines for each deliverable can be found in the course schedule above.

The term paper involves the completion of an extensive survey of the scientific literature on a relevant topic (e.g. remote sensing, numerical modeling or in-situ studies of any element of the cryosphere; cryosphere-climate interactions on a variety of space and time scales; the representation of elements of the cryosphere in climate or weather prediction models; the impact of changes in any element or a group of elements of the cryosphere on Society).

course_name: GEOG407 - Environmental Hydrology of Terrestrial Ecosystems (0.50)
major_name: Earth Systems Science Specialization
topics: Environmental Hydrology of Terrestrial Ecosystems Winter 2025
merrin.macrae@uwaterloo.ca
Email: mmacrae@uwaterloo.ca
This course focuses on ecological and biogeochemical processes that are linked to the terrestrial hydrological cycle and how these relate to the management of natural resources.

The objectives of this interdisciplinary course are to explore topics that integrate ecosystem processes with physical hydrology and examine the impacts of human activities on ecohydrological and hydrochemical processes within terrestrial systems.
Understand linkages between hydrological and biogeochemical processes in the natural environment
Understand the implications of land use change and climate change on selected ecosystems
Analyze and visualize numerical data and write laboratory reports
Jan. 14 Watershed Hydrology Field and Lab Methods for Water Quality 1 *Safety/services & orientation of labs; TAs do overview of labs
Feb. 25 Wetlands and In-stream Processes  *Data Lab Part 2
Mar. 4 Impacts of Climate Change on hydrology and biogeochem: case study of subarctic and temperate peatlands *Data Lab Part 2
Each lab section will attend a total of two “practical labs” – one will be held outdoors in the field and the other will be held indoors in a laboratory setting.
For the indoor lab, students will learn standard techniques for the processing of samples and the analyses of key water quality parameters.
This time of year can be cold and wet – students must have proper clothing to stay warm and dry for 1.5 hours in the field.
The meticulous construction of lab reports or field reports is a hallmark of any undergraduate education in geography and environmental sciences.
The careful analysis of hydrological and water quality data is also critical in water quality research and is a skill necessary to succeed in jobs in this field.

These labs will introduce you to the exploration and analysis of standard parameters in water quality analysis, by working with the data and constructing informative tables and graphs and describing what your data is showing you.
The exam will consist of a series of multiple choice, short answer and longer essay-style questions.

This course includes the independent development and practice of specific skills, such as understanding the importance of proper data collection and analysis, as well as the interpretation of these data.

course_name: COMMST191 - Communication in the Engineering Profession (AE, CIVE, ENVE, GEOE) (0.50)
major_name: Geological Engineering (Bachelor of Applied Science - Honours)
topics: jclausen@uwaterloo.ca (please do not use the D2L email system)
I monitor my email M-F, 9:00 am - 5:00 pm.
I am teaching multiple communication courses, and especially early in the sememster, I cannot always quickly know whch course you are referring to just from your email.
In this course students in Architectural, Civil, Environmental, and Geological Engineering will enhance oral and written communication competencies in contexts relevant to the engineering profession.
In this course, you will work to enhance your written and oral technical communication competencies in contexts relevant to the engineering profession as well as to your future career.

More generally, in this course, you should anticipate learning what professional norms of technical communication and dominant forms of sharing knowledge prevail within and across the fields of engineering.
Yet this course also attempts to impart awareness and appreciation for how these communicative forms are matters of social context and sites of negotiation and contestation.

By extension, this progression also encourages you to find a place and voice in the conversations within your fields of study and to reflect upon the meaning and shape of available forums for technical communication.
I perceive our classroom as a co-constructed space, in which readings and discussions may frequently challenge your attitudes, your unconsciously held beliefs, or your positions on current issues.
To ensure a safe and open space in which all can converse and learn productively, it is vital that we conduct our relationships with respect and an ethic of care.
Describe and apply conventions, genres, norms, and values of communication in an engineering discipline;
Compose persuasive, audience-specific technical arguments;
Analyze and summarice technical content in clear and concise ways;
Deliver effective oral presentations; and
Appraise and reflect on their own compositions, and those of their peers, to strategically revise and edit documents and presentations
Objectives for Students of Communication Studies
You (students) will understand the complexity of communication as a human process of shared meaning-making in the context of power, history, and culture.

You will increase your capacity to recognize and enhance yours and others’ agency – the ability to make a difference in the world for yourself and others – and understand the implications of your communication behaviors for yourself and others.
Recognize diverse linguistic practices and modes of communication as resources for writers and speakers.

You will understand communication as a practice, and improve your critical and creative communication competencies by developing your ability to use writing, speaking, and other media of communication to create effective and engaging artifacts.

Your will reflect on your role in fostering the public good (the multifaceted well-being of individuals and groups), begin to imagine a better future, and make decisions in your communication that can transform the communities to which you belong.

In this assignment, you will choose a specific topic related to civil engineering and identify an overarching problem to produce a project proposal.

In this assignment you will creating a proposal in response to an imagined request for proposals (RFP) from a contractor in the industry, and presenting that proposal in a short three-minute pitch for your classmates, who will consider the persuasiveness of your proposal.
Failures of retaining walls
Failures of suspension bridges
Importance and justification of arches
Role of surveying in engineering
In groups of 2 or 3, you will provide a technical summary of that element for a public, non-specialist audience.
You will present a summary of the project element as a poster presentation on a standard 24x36 inch poster board using a combination of written and graphic communication.

We may be involved in a public displaying of the posters we create, alongside students from other sections of Engineering Communication on evening in February over in one of the Engineering buildings.
Part 2: Research Abstract
The abstract should provide information relevant to solutions to the problem you articulated in your proposal and continue to advocate for a particular solution/recommendations.
For the final project you will create a policy brief aimed at a clear stakeholder audience.
Instructions
A formal policy brief includes the following sections:
Executive summary
Explanation of results
identify and address a specific policy-making audience
explain the current research on this topic in clear, non-technical language
highlight the features of the research most relevant for policy makers and stakeholders
make one or two recommendations based on your synthesis of the research
Natural Resource Development
Climate Change Impact
Mass Transportation Design

topics: Linear Algebra Fall 2024
WEEF TAs are also available but students are strongly encouraged to seek help first from a member of the teaching team.
Linear systems of equations, matrices, and determinants.
Introduction to the eigenvalue problem.

This course introduces fundamental linear algebra concepts such as linear systems of equations, matrices, vector spaces, and the eigenvalue problem with emphasis on applications used by civil, environmental, geological, and architectural engineers.
Construct and systematically solve systems of linear equations.
Predict the solution properties given the properties of the system.
Construct vectors and perform vector operations (e.g., length, dot, and cross products) by hand.
Identify and solve basic eigenvalue and eigenvector problems.

Linear systems of two and three variables, substitution, elimination, graphical solutions; ordered lists, vectors, parameters; Systems of equations as matrices and vectors, elementary row operations, reduced row echelon form, Gaussian elimination, rank, independent and dependent equations, solution sets; homogeneous systems and solutions

Matrices: general, vectors, zero, transpose, square, diagonal, triangular, identity, symmetric; rank, independent and dependent rows and columns; Matrix arithmetic: equality, addition, scalar multiplication, matrix multiplication; Inverse matrix: procedure, properties, inverse method of solving a system; Elementary matrices

Vectors in Rn: standard and geometric, addition and scalar multiplication, length, unit vectors; vector equations of lines, planes and hyperplanes; dot product, projections, cross and box product in 3D; linear independence, linear dependence, span, basis, change of basis
Matrix-vector multiplication as a linear transformation;
Eigenvalues and eigenvectors: definition, procedure, interpretation;
A First Course in Linear Algebra: an Open Text, by Lyryx Learning, Version 2017 Revision A, based on original text by K. Kuttler, 2012.
The use of a basic scientific calculator is allowed in this course.

Keith Delaney

Email: anne.allen@uwaterloo.ca

Azi Zebarjadian - a2zebarj@uwaterloo.ca
The course develops a geological knowledge for applications to any physical environment and provides an appreciation of the impact of engineering work on the environment.
Topics include mineral and rock identification, the rock cycle, structural geology and tectonics, geology of Canada, effects of water, ice and wind.
Students are also introduced to the concept of geologic time, topographic and geologic maps, and the basic principles and tools used to determine geologic history.
Gain insight into why engineers are continually challenged by the science behind a complex and changing earth.
Understand and apply engineering design principles in the context of a changing earth.
Gain basic experience in identifying earth materials and in earth material testing.
Establish the academic background required to take advanced earth sciences and geotechnical engineering courses.
Geology and Soils Labs: This course includes seven laboratory sessions that will be held during the term.
Students need to self-organize into case study groups, with the same number of students in each group.

major_name: Geological Engineering (Bachelor of Applied Science - Honours)
topics: Earth Engineering Spring 2024
Monday, Friday -
The course develops a geological knowledge for applications to any physical environment and provides an appreciation of the impact of engineering work on the environment.
Topics include mineral and rock identification, the rock cycle, structural geology and tectonics, geology of Canada, effects of water, ice and wind.
Students are also introduced to the concept of geologic time, topographic and geologic maps, and the basic principles and tools used to determine geologic history.
Gain insight into why engineers are continually challenged by the science behind a complex and changing earth.
Understand and apply engineering design principles in the context of a changing earth.
Gain basic experience in identifying earth materials and in earth material testing.
Establish the academic background required to take advanced earth sciences and geotechnical engineering courses.

course_name: ENVE223 - Differential Equations and Balance Laws (0.50)
major_name: Geological Engineering (Bachelor of Applied Science - Honours)
topics: Differential Equations and Balance Laws Winter 2025
An introduction to ordinary differential equations with applications to mass and energy balance problems in engineering.
Standard methods of solution of first and second order linear equations with constant coefficients.
Numerical methods for solving ordinary differential equations.

Many practical physical and engineering problems can be analyzed using mathematical models formulated in terms of ordinary differential equations; these often arise from the application of mass, momentum, or energy balance laws.
The objective of this course is to equip engineering students with a working knowledge of the methods which are used to solve these equations.
Differential equations are introduced, along with standard methods of solution for first and second order linear equations with constant coefficients.
identify and differentiate between the various types of differential equations; with this knowledge, be able to identify the most appropriate method of solution
pose appropriate boundary or initial conditions and solve that equation using standard methods for given a mathematical problem statement expressed in terms of a linear differential equation
check whether a solution to a differential equation is correct
think critically about a mathematical problem and evaluate the validity of results from mathematical methods
appreciate the utility and value of having an education in mathematics as part of their training as an engineer

The Statics portion of the course mainly involves three-dimensional force system analysis and the Solid Mechanics course content is focused on examining material response (i.e., stress and strain conditions) in different sections/members under external loads.
Specific topics include transverse shear, torsion of shafts, treatment of compound stresses, and the introduction of beam deflections and basic design concepts.

The primary objective of this course is to provide students with conceptual knowledge to analyse simple structural systems and to evaluate the mechanical response of the structural components comprising these systems.
Calculate distributions and magnitudes of stresses in elements subjected to shear, torsion, bending, and combinations thereof
Construct axial force, shear force, and bending moment diagrams for beams and frame elements
Determine deflected beam shapes and compute the magnitudes of deflections at key locations
Design simple beams to satisfy strength and/or service criteria

At the University of Waterloo, Dr. Johnston teaches numerous classes such as Earth 121 - Introductory Earth Sciences, Earth 235 - Stratigraphic Approaches to Understanding Earth's History, Earth 390 - Methods in Geological Field Mapping, and occasional graduate classes such as Earth 691 Special Studies for MSc Students (i.e. Coastal Geology).

He is a board member for the University of Waterloo Earth Science Museum and representative for the Geological Association of Canada on the North American Commission on Stratigraphic Nomenclature (former chair and vice chair).

The development of stratigraphic sequences as controlled by global and regional tectonics and sea level fluctuations.

topics: Notice of Recording
Field Methods in Hydrogeology Fall 2024
An introduction to the principles and theories of mineral deposit genesis.
Basic technical, economic, legal, and ethical aspects of mineral exploration and responsible development of natural resources are also covered.
View requirements for EARTH 458L
Applied geophysics provides geoscientists with a wide-range of non-invasive methods for characterizing the Earth's interior.

This course is an introduction to the physical principles underlying field acquisition, processing, and data interpretation for commonly used applied geophysical techniques (seismic, electrical, electromagnetic induction, gravity, and magnetic methods).

This course is not only pertinent for geoscientists but also for engineers and others interested in learning how physics can be used to explore the Earth's interior or perform non-destructive testing.
Near-surface geophysics is used to characterize the shallow subsurface for a wide-spectrum of applications.
This application-oriented course covers current methodology in near-surface geophysics, including electrical, electromagnetic, ground penetrating radar, seismic refraction, and well-logging methods.
Techniques for geophysical data acquisition and interpretation are studied and applied to field data.
Examples of the application of geophysical techniques to archeological, forensics, geotechnical, glaciology, and hydrogeological problems are examined.
View requirements for EARTH 461
A field-oriented course on current methodology in the general area of geotechnical or engineering geophysics as applied to environmental problems.

Typical topics covered: well logging and time domain electromagnetic surveys for groundwater supply; magnetic and terrain conductivity surveys for waste materials; ground penetrating radar applications to stratigraphy and contamination; streaming potential surveys of dam leakage.
A pre-lab quiz must be completed before attending each field lab.
Labs will be completed in groups with field data recorded in field books or datasheets.
These data will be used to a complete individual lab assignment.
This site contains over 100 groundwater monitoring wells.
Field lab activities involve:
(3) Measurement of in-situ hydraulic conductivity using single-well response tests
Each lab will provide you with a unique dataset that you will use to develop a conceptual site model of the local groundwater flow system.
• Properly construct and interpret soil core logs using United Soil Classification System, and make lithostratigraphic interpretations using geophysical logs
• Assess and interpret water level measurements through the construction of water table maps and flownets
• Interpret single-well response tests including falling and rising head (slug) tests to determine in-situ hydraulic conductivity
• Interpret hydraulic pumping tests to determine aquifer transmissivity and storage parameters and assess water resource vulnerability
Each module will contain a series of recorded lecture slides and video demonstrations reviewing core concepts and guidelines for the upcoming field lab.

major_name: Geological Engineering (Bachelor of Applied Science - Honours)
topics: Notice of Recording
Field Methods in Hydrogeology Fall 2024
An introduction to the principles and theories of mineral deposit genesis.
Basic technical, economic, legal, and ethical aspects of mineral exploration and responsible development of natural resources are also covered.
View requirements for EARTH 458L
Applied geophysics provides geoscientists with a wide-range of non-invasive methods for characterizing the Earth's interior.

This course is an introduction to the physical principles underlying field acquisition, processing, and data interpretation for commonly used applied geophysical techniques (seismic, electrical, electromagnetic induction, gravity, and magnetic methods).

This course is not only pertinent for geoscientists but also for engineers and others interested in learning how physics can be used to explore the Earth's interior or perform non-destructive testing.
Near-surface geophysics is used to characterize the shallow subsurface for a wide-spectrum of applications.
This application-oriented course covers current methodology in near-surface geophysics, including electrical, electromagnetic, ground penetrating radar, seismic refraction, and well-logging methods.
Techniques for geophysical data acquisition and interpretation are studied and applied to field data.
Examples of the application of geophysical techniques to archeological, forensics, geotechnical, glaciology, and hydrogeological problems are examined.
View requirements for EARTH 461
A field-oriented course on current methodology in the general area of geotechnical or engineering geophysics as applied to environmental problems.

Typical topics covered: well logging and time domain electromagnetic surveys for groundwater supply; magnetic and terrain conductivity surveys for waste materials; ground penetrating radar applications to stratigraphy and contamination; streaming potential surveys of dam leakage.
A pre-lab quiz must be completed before attending each field lab.
Labs will be completed in groups with field data recorded in field books or datasheets.
These data will be used to a complete individual lab assignment.
This site contains over 100 groundwater monitoring wells.
Field lab activities involve:
(3) Measurement of in-situ hydraulic conductivity using single-well response tests
Each lab will provide you with a unique dataset that you will use to develop a conceptual site model of the local groundwater flow system.
• Properly construct and interpret soil core logs using United Soil Classification System, and make lithostratigraphic interpretations using geophysical logs
• Assess and interpret water level measurements through the construction of water table maps and flownets
• Interpret single-well response tests including falling and rising head (slug) tests to determine in-situ hydraulic conductivity
• Interpret hydraulic pumping tests to determine aquifer transmissivity and storage parameters and assess water resource vulnerability
Each module will contain a series of recorded lecture slides and video demonstrations reviewing core concepts and guidelines for the upcoming field lab.

topics: Rock mechanics principles and design procedures in areas of mining, civil engineering, and petroleum engineering.

ROCK MECHANICS & ROCK ENGINEERING
Course content in relation to prerequisite courses
Scope, capabilities & applications of rock mechanics
Discussion of On Line Information Sources for engineers and scientists
Discussion of RISK in engineering design and operation, in different industries
DESIGN PRINCIPLES
Uncertainties in design, concept of modelling, types of model
--Introduction to probabilistic concepts in design; safety factors in civil, mining and petroleum
--Conceptual, mathematical, empirical, physical, probabilistic models
Parametric studies (sensitivity analyses) as a design tool
Empirical design & expert systems (review); use of knowledge sources and data bases
Analog and physical models (review); assessment of mechanisms
Analytical solutions & numerical modeling
Limitations and role of laboratory and field testing in rock mechanics (overview)
Estimation of the past and future load history and geometry evolution
Development of a sufficient behavioral law for the problem to be addressed
Confirmation of the design validity and continued optimization by monitoring and re-analyzing
**Assignment 1 on Design Approaches and Uncertainty in Rock Engineering.
FORCE AND STRESS
Mass and weight, forces, stresses and strengths, vectors & tensors
Calculation of total and effective stresses in sedimentary basins
Slow compaction and lithification of sediments, continental drift and mantle processes
Stress on a surface & elemental cube; shear and normal stress calculation on an arbitrary plane
Gravitational stresses, effects of depth and topography
At-rest stress state, loading and unloading effects, stress history and diagenesis
Tectonic stresses, "fossilized" stresses, intercrystalline stresses and core microfracturing and disking
Limits to earth stresses, active and passive limits for sediments, effect of cohesion
Limits to stresses in jointed rocks, slip of joints, effect of fissured masses
Measured soil & rock stress trends, unloading of strata
Stresses in creeping rock strata such as shale and halite
Stresses near the earth's surfaces and at depth; depth and intensity of earthquakes
Stress trajectories in the earth, changes because of tectonic and volcanic effects
Estimation of stress states in sediments; basin models and structural geology principles
Stress measurement methods in soils & rocks: nulling, strain-relief, and direct methods
Nulling methods: slotting stress meter, undercoring & flat jack methods
Direct methods: liquid inclusion, hydraulic fracturing & hydraulic tests on preexisting fissures
**Assignment 2 on Stresses in the Earth: calculations, measurements, estimations
Definitions of strength & yield criteria; peak strength and ultimate strength
The difference between residual mineral strength and ultimate rock mass strength
Strength & yield criteria in 2-D stress space (t-sn' and p-q diagrams)
Uniaxial, biaxial, polyaxial, hydrostatic compression tests
Effect of scale on strength, large-scale triaxial tests in the laboratory
Direct & indirect tensile tests, beam bending, torsion and hollow cylinder tests
Tilt tests on blocks & core, rock-to-rock surface required
Triaxial testing of discontinuities - limitations
Sampling of jointed rock & filling materials, taking and testing replicas
Direct shear test with laboratory & field‑portable apparatus
In situ tests on blocks, slopes and underground testing
Estimating shear strength from back analysis
The effects of increasing normal stress on porous and non-porous rocks
Dilatant behavior & i-angle, curvilinear criteria overview, scale & roughness effects
Shear strength criteria, Mohr‑Coulomb strengths of joints and fillings
Attributes of the strength surface
Mohr‑Coulomb criterion, Griffith criterion and extensions
Crack initiation & propagation, Griffith crack theory, extensional strain fracture criteria
Modes of rupture & yield associated with brittle behavior and different stresses
A proposed mechanism for rock bursting
Fracture toughness tests for fracture mechanics
Mechanisms of brittle rupture in blasting, hydraulic fracture
STRAIN AND DEFORMATION:
CONCEPTS & MEASUREMENT
Elastic and inelastic behaviour, linear and non-linear behaviour
Strain and deformation, reversible and irreversible straining, non-linearity of deformation processes
Strain localization because of weakening, localization of slip along joints in a rock mass
Strain paths for 2-D cases in typical situations such as mining a free vertical face,
Anisotropy of rock deformability: principal directions of stiffness, example of shales
Uniaxial compression test & derivation of elastic parameters
Volumetric strain measurements in triaxial tests, dilation of rock matrix and joint surfaces
Joint stiffness & compliance, shear stiffness versus shear displacement
FIELD TESTS OF ROCK AND ROCK MASS DEFORMABILITY
Flexible CSM dilatometer & rigid Goodman Jack
Plate loading tests, surface & underground, rigid & flexible plates
Radial jacking & pressure tests in tunnels
STRESS‑STRAIN CURVES FOR SOILS & ROCKS
Typical static-elastic parameters & behavior of various rock types
Dilatancy suppression as the effect of normal stress; increasing damage with dilatancy reduction
Comparison of laboratory & field results
Stress waves and their velocities in different rocks
Measurement of wave velocity & dynamic elastic parameters
Typical dynamic elastic properties, difference between static & dynamic values
Time- and temperature-dependence of strength and strain
Conventional "primary-secondary-tertiary" creep concepts
The concept of steady-state fabric and increasing damage in covalent bonded rocks
Laboratory uniaxial & triaxial creep tests
Stress relaxation & strain‑rate controlled tests
Field tests & back analysis; trial rooms and convergence measurements
Rheological elements & simple rheological "bodies"
Non-linear elastic, plastic (slip and rupture), and viscous parameters
Creep behavior of typical soft & hard rocks
**Assignment 4 on Rock Deformation: compressibility, deformation, calculation of moduli, creep, swelling, and thermal effects in rocks: rheological models, simple calculations
Slopes in Mining Engineering versus Slopes in Civil Engineering
The Safety Factor concept and the Probability of Slip concept
Slowly creeping slopes – clay shales in Western Canada
Earthquake triggered slides – quick clay slides in ON, QC
Impacts of rainfall events
Deep weathering in crystalline rocks and impact on joint strength
VECTOR ANALYSIS AND LIMITING EQUILIBRIUM METHODS
The infinite slope sliding along a pressurized basal plane
--Vectorial analysis using forces
--Development of equations, design charts
--Design charts and making a problem dimensionless for plotting
Using a simple model of slope yield to incorporate uncertainty – the Monte Carlo method
--Porous, permeable thermal reservoir
The disposal reservoir
--Biosolids injection and sequestration of carbon in solid form
Closed-form solution derivations for the lateral stress changes in a reservoir
CLOSED-FORM SOLUTIONS FOR CIRCULAR OPENINGS IN ELASTIC ROCK
The Lamé hollow cylinder equations
--Derivation of hydraulic fracture equations for an impermeable, pressurized elastic borehole
--State of stress in the elastic tunnel or borehole wall in a deviatoric stress field
--Closed-form solution for thermal stresses on the wall of a circular opening because of DT
--Use of a borehole stability software package
DVELOPING AND STABILIZING UNDERGROUND OPENINGS
--Support systems
The use of such solutions as a guide to engineering practice
**Assignment 7 on Circular Openings: the tunnel and a fissure, the fracture equations, typical stress distributions
Establishment of baseline data
Confirmation of analytical and design assumptions
Process optimization during development and operations – Adaptive Management in Geo Engineering
The uses of direct observation
Alarms, limit switches, designing software for continuous analysis
Multi-arm calipers, geophysical log methods
Geophysical borehole logging methods
Temperature and pressure monitoring installations in deep boreholes
Active seismic methods, X-hole seismic tomography, time-lapse methods
Gravity surveys, magnetic surveys
Surface and subsurface tiltmeter arrays
Microseismic monitoring
**Assignment 8 on Monitoring and Design Verification in Rock Mechanics

The Introduction to Rock Mechanics course will repeatedly emphasize to the student the importance of understanding limitations and risks that must be managed in a Professional context, including issues such as responsibilities and ethics in design and reporting (Read the additional document on Information Sources and Ethics)
The design process in Geomechanics will be outlined as a process of risk management and continual design and project outcomes improvement
The student will learn to appreciate the importance of Earth Stresses and how to measure or estimate them, and be able to do depth and stress-pressure calculations

It is an expectation that the student knows what deformation-based design is and how to estimate and measure the deformability of rock at all scales from the laboratory to the field, for Civil, Mining and Petroleum Engineering applications, including foundations design, prediction compaction behavior

A basic comprehension of Yield and “Failure” of rock specimens and rock masses, including failure mechanisms, the yield behavior of joints, dilation, Mohr-Coulomb yield criteria, ultimate strength, use of Mohr-Coulomb diagrams to evaluate strength and proximity to strain-weakening yield, is expected as part of the design environment in rock mechanics
What is rheological modelling and its role in breaking down complex stress-strain-yield constitutive behavior into simpler elements to help understand the elements of constitutive laws and physics?
What are the basic mechanics and physics of creep in rock and rock masses (with some emphasis on salt mechanics)?

Doing slope stability analysis using limiting equilibrium of forces methods, including understanding how to incorporate forces arising from pore pressures, earthquake loading, self-weight, tensioned cables, and other factors into slope stability assessment.
Introduction to stress concentrations arising around circular openings and other structures in RM, using the Kirsch equations for stresses around a circular borehole.
Students are introduced to this analysis for first-order estimates of borehole yield, and sequenced/observational methods for tunneling in naturally jointed rock masses are introduced.
Calculating effective stress changes and proximity to strain-weakening yield based on stress and yield criterion analysis

Although the course does not involve mathematical modeling (numerical simulation) directly, everyone in RM areas and other engineering domains will be using numerical modeling approaches in their careers.
The concept of THMC coupling will be introduced
Introduction to some special topics will be undertaken in the final several lectures to help open the student to interesting development and directions in Geomechanics.
For example, shale gas and shale oil geoengineering, CO2 sequestration, and geothermal energy are important emerging areas that are rich in RM issues

While research (i.e., discovery of new knowledge) may be an important component of engineering design, research-only projects are not appropriate for Engineering Capstone Design Projects.
A five-person team will require a special plan to do more work than the normal four person teams.
Each design team will choose an appropriate Environmental/Geological engineering problem that reflects the interests of the team members.
Teams must select a challenging design problem.
A challenging problem is one where you have few, if any, alternative designs in mind to start the project.

Teams must demonstrate that a range of design alternatives were considered.
Teams must quantitatively evaluate multiple alternatives and multiple design objectives/constraints (e.g., engineering analysis and engineering decision-making).

The standard project will demonstrate this alternative generation and decision-making in this 400 course, however, in some projects, it could be more natural to save the alternative generation and decision-making application to the next term (in 401).
Such an arrangement must be approved on a case-by-case basis by Professor Tolson who may choose to consult with your technical advisor.

keeping their team on track and constructively motivate other team members,

Advanced concepts on wetland ecosystems in the context of regional and global earth systems processes such as carbon and nitrogen cycling and climate change, applications of wetland paleoecology, use of isotopes and other geochemical tools in wetland science, and wetland engineering in landscape rehabilitation and ecotechnology.
Current issues in Canada and abroad will be examined.
